title: Bookham Commons Walking Route

images.title: Chris Reynolds / Leaning over the Water, Bookham Common
images.caption: Leaning over the Water, Bookham Common. The earth dam, which keeps the pond in place, can be seen running across the picture.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / On Bayfield Plain, Bookham Common
images.caption: On Bayfield Plain, Bookham Common. The brown area has recently been flailed. The newsletter by the entrance explains: Local cattle will be returning to the plains to help munch-down the competitive vegetation, maintaining a grassland rich in wild flowers. This year they have been given a helping hand with a tractor flail, knowking down the invasive birch and willow saplings which were too large for the cattle to reach.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / A Path through the Woodland on Bookham Common
images.caption: A path through the Woodland on the common. In addition to a number of tracks, and formal footpaths, there are many other paths, such as this one, ideal for dog walking. At this time of year much of the green under-storey here is holly.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / Bookham Stream, Bookham Common
images.caption: Bookham Stream, In practice a muddy ditch which in places is almost completely obscured by vegetation  but which expands to a tiny pool by the track junction.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / Walkway across the Marsh, Bookham Common
images.caption: Walkway across the Marsh. This provides a way of permitting people to see a march at close hand without destroying an interesting habitat.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / The Western Pond, Bookham Common
images.caption: The Western Pond. A shallow valley runs across the Common and several low earth dams have created a series of ponds and marshy areas a paradise for wild life.

images.title: Chris Reynolds / An Overcast Day on Bookham Common
images.caption: An Overcast Day on the common sees a dog making its way along one of the footpaths. This area represents rare grassland, full of wild flowers, insects, small mammals, and amphibians. Clumps of scrub give shelter to a great range of birds, and many butterflies can be seen. The commons would be quickly become overgrown unless careful rotational clearing is carries out and cattle have been introduced on part of the plains, because this is the finest way of managing grassland and scrub to maintain ecological diversity. (Based on text on map board by entrance).

images.title: Chris Reynolds / Hadleys Cottage. Isle of Wight, Bookham Common
images.caption: Hadleys Cottage. Isle of Wight. In the middle of the Commons there is a small unwooded area, named the Isle of Wight, which contains a number of private properties, including Hadleys Cottage.

description: This large area of common land is located just to the west of Leatherhead. It's a good place for walking with miles of trails taking you to grassland, ancient woodland and picturesque ponds. The common includes bridleways which are suitable for cyclists as well. It's a great place for wildlife too with nightingales, warblers and pretty butterflies in the summer months. There is a handy bird hide on the eastern side of the site, next to the ponds. There's an information board here detailing the birds you might see on the water. Keep your eyes peeled for little grebe and damselflies here. This walk starts from the National Trust car park at the southern end of the common. Very close by is Bookham train station so the common is very accessible by public transport. From here you can pick up the footpaths heading north west and then create a circular route through the area.
